info.game_comments:
John Ryan game 2.

Portions of this show appear in Season 1, Episode 7 of of the Netflix series GLOW, set in 1985.

(1, 1).clue: In per-store gross, White Castle was #1 in 1984 fast food business, edging out this huge competitor

(2, 1).clue: The L.A. Times called this the "sport of kings, queens & pawns"

(3, 1).clue: Incubation among these huge flightless birds is done by females during the day & males at night

(4, 1).clue: A shelter for dogs, it's from the Latin "canis" meaning "dog"

(5, 1).clue: She convinced a judge to cut 10 years off her legal age - perhaps by saying "coochi-coochi"

(6, 1).clue: Experts say to avoid wrinkles around the eyes, stop smoking & wear a pair of these outside during day

(1, 2).clue: One version says the name of this product was inspired by a picture of William Penn

(2, 2).clue: Guinness says Con McCarrick once played 154 games of this, also called draughts, simultaneously

(3, 2).clue: To display his gorgeous feathers, the blue bird of paradise hangs like this while courting

(4, 2).clue: A hard or chewy candy made of brown sugar & butter

(5, 2).clue: As a Future Farmer of America he raised blue-ribbon hogs, but his Farm Aid raised funds for farmers

(6, 2).clue: In August '86, the Air Force announced it had accidentally dropped one of these on New Mexico in '57

(1, 3).clue: This Texas department store's 1965 catalogue had a page "How to Spend $1 Million" there

(2, 3).clue: Shape of the windowed piece that players - or spirits - move around the Ouija board

(3, 3).clue: To feed their newborn, a type of "milk" is produced by both parents of these common city birds

(4, 3).clue: On July 25, 1986, Los Angeles saw it at 7:59 p.m. PDT

(5, 3).clue: Billed as "The Other Sheena", this singer's ex-husband impersonates her in nightclubs

(6, 3).clue: Of 6%, 21%, or 53%, percentage of U.S. mail comprised of personal letters

(1, 4).clue: Cincinnati-based company that makes largest selling toothpaste, detergent, & dandruff shampoo in U.S.

(2, 4).clue: Mia Farrow used the letters in this game to decipher a witchy anagram in "Rosemary's Baby"

(4, 4).clue: In Matthew, chapters 5-7, Jesus delivered one "on the mount"

(5, 4).clue: He not only wrote songs for Jim Henson's film "Labyrinth", but played the Goblin King

(6, 4).clue: While she is judged in one, Miss America is forbidden to wear one in public after winning

(1, 5).clue: Big holes were 1st put in '45s to force buyers to use players "initially" made only by this company

(2, 5).clue: In backgammon, each player starts out with this number of men on the board

(4, 5).clue: This lighter-than-air element only rose to #2 on the periodic chart

(5, 5).clue: Maybe "Monkee" business kept him away: he only joined the other Monkees once on their '86 tour

(6, 5).clue: Among videos with this feature for hearing impaired are "Care Bears II" & "Playboy Centerfold 3"

(1, 1).clue: The population of this capital city is about 2/3 Mormon

(2, 1).clue: It sounds fancier in French, but "oeufs frits" are merely these

(3, 1).clue: At age 8, this Civil War era President was the only Protestant student in a Catholic school

(4, 1).clue: According to Burns & Mantle's, "Best Plays" titles with this # of words were big during '82-83 season

(6, 1).clue: Author who sent characters "Around the World", "Under the Sea", & "To the Center of the Earth"

(1, 2).clue: Providence, R.I. & this large New England city are the two capitals closest to each other

(2, 2).clue: Often served a la vinaigrette, "tete de veau" is this part of a calf

(3, 2).clue: This arch-villain in "Uncle Tom's Cabin" was a northerner

(4, 2).clue: In '84-'85 season, only 3 new shows recouped costs: Whoopi Goldberg, "Hurlyburly" & this classic set in Siam

(6, 2).clue: Thousands of game show contestants have departed with this man's watches on their wrists

(1, 3).clue: Not surprisingly, the state capitol building in this city was designed by Thomas Jefferson

(2, 3).clue: If your "canard", or duck, is "sauvage", it's this - or was this, before you shot it

(3, 3).clue: Preacher H. Ward Beecher is said to have sent Sharps rifles to John Brown in crates labeled as these

(4, 3).clue: "Big River", a musical with songs by singer Roger Miller, is based on this classic American novel

(5, 3).clue: Maternal name of the principal vein of silver or gold, or so we're told

(6, 3).clue: Paul Mazursky's 1980 film "Willie & Phil" was based in part on this classic 1961 Truffaut film

(1, 4).clue: Dirt poor, riding a borrowed horse & carrying everything with him, Lincoln arrived here on April 15, 1837

(2, 4).clue: Breakfast treat whose name may be derived from "briser", to break, & "hocher", to shake

(3, 4).clue: In 1858 S.C. Senator James "Mudsill" Hammond said, "You dare not make war on cotton.  Cotton is" this

(4, 4).clue: Musical about this red-haired doll reached Broadway in 1986 after playing Moscow 1st

(5, 4).clue: Semiprecious stone colored deep blue by the mineral lazurite

(6, 4).clue: French equivalent of Sherlock Holmes introduced in 1931 by Georges Simenon

(1, 5).clue: In the late 19th c., a branch of the U.S. Mint was operated in this capital named for a famous frontiersman

(2, 5).clue: Some eat this "anguille" glazed with fish jelly & arranged in a coil

(3, 5).clue: While Confederate General Jackson was nicknamed "Stonewall", his real 1st name was this

(4, 5).clue: This husband-wife team starred in "Foxfire" onstage before going into a "Cocoon" onscreen

(5, 5).clue: Chalk is a form of this sedimentary rock

(6, 5).clue: This Village Voice cartoonist could have his black-leotarded dancer do a dance to Jeopardy!

(0, 0).clue: This Eng. king who saved his country from conquest & promoted learning is the only 1 called "the Great"
